skill.name: commit-helper
skill.description: Intelligent commit message generation following conventional commit format.
skill.summary: Generates conventional git commit messages by analyzing staged changes.
skill.author: CuriousLearner

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The 'network' finding is a metadata URL field. 'C2 keywords' and 'weak cryptographic algorithm' detections are benign documentation terms like 'command', 'execute', 'fix:', 'BREAKING CHANGE'. The 'external_commands' findings document legitimate git commands that Claude executes via its built-in tools, not shell backticks. This is a standard commit message helper skill with no security risks.

content.value_statement: Writing clear commit messages is difficult. This skill analyzes your staged changes and generates conventional commit messages that follow industry best practices for better project history.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes staged git changes using git diff --staged
Categorizes commits into types like feat, fix, docs, style, refactor
Generates conventional commit messages with proper format
Reviews git history to match project commit style
Creates subject lines with imperative mood and character limits
limitations: Does not execute git commands directly; relies on Claude tools
Cannot detect semantic meaning beyond code diff analysis
Does not integrate with issue trackers directly

use_cases.title: Automate Commit Messages for New Features
use_cases.description: Automatically generate conventional commit messages when adding new features to your codebase.

use_cases.title: Standardize Team Commit History
use_cases.description: Ensure all team members write consistent, readable commit messages that follow conventional commit standards.

use_cases.title: Quick Bug Fix Documentation
use_cases.description: Quickly document bug fixes with clear, concise messages that explain the problem and solution.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Commit Generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a conventional commit message for my staged changes. Use @commit-helper to analyze the diff and create an appropriate message.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you have staged changes and need a commit message

prompt_templates.title: Scoped Feature Commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a commit message for my staged feature changes. Scope it to the authentication module.
prompt_templates.scenario: When working on a specific module or component

prompt_templates.title: Fix with Breaking Change
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a commit message for my changes. This includes a breaking change to the API response format.
prompt_templates.scenario: When making breaking changes that affect the API

prompt_templates.title: Documentation Update
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a commit message for these documentation changes only.
prompt_templates.scenario: When updating docs, READMEs, or code comments

Implement automatic token refresh to improve user experience

- Add refresh token endpoint
- Update auth middleware to handle token expiry

Fixes #456

output_examples.output:

Previous implementation threw error on null input.
Now returns false for null/undefined values.

output_examples.input: Staged changes: Updated API documentation for v2 endpoints

best_practices: Run git diff --staged before generating commits to ensure all relevant changes are staged
Provide context about the business problem solved by the changes
Review the generated message and adjust the scope or body as needed
anti_patterns: Using generated messages without reviewing the content for accuracy
Staging only partial changes and expecting complete context
Ignoring the conventional commit format requirements

faq.question: What is the conventional commit format?
faq.answer: Conventional commits use the format: type(scope): subject. Types include feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, perf, test, chore, ci, and revert. The optional body explains the change and the footer references issues.

faq.question: Does this skill execute git commands?
faq.answer: No, this skill analyzes staged changes and generates commit messages. Claude executes git commands through its built-in tools when you request them.

faq.question: Can I customize the commit types?
faq.answer: The skill follows standard conventional commit types. You can specify scope and type in your request, such as @commit-helper --scope api --type fix.

faq.question: What if my project uses a different commit style?
faq.answer: The skill checks git log to match your project's existing style. You can also specify your project's conventions in the request.

faq.question: How long should the commit message body be?
faq.answer: The subject line should be 50 characters or less. Wrap body text at 72 characters. Focus on explaining the what and why, not the how.

faq.question: Can this skill handle breaking changes?
faq.answer: Yes, include breaking change information in your request. The skill will format it correctly with BREAKING CHANGE in the footer.
